prompt:
Human: Are cats deadly allergic to any kinds of foods?

Assistant: No. They don’t have anything called an “allergic reaction” because they don’t have the same immune system we do. They don’t have itchy noses, they don’t have red spots on their skin, they don’t have lumps in their armpits. What’s called “food allergy” is a form of anaphylaxis, an unusual and dangerous allergic reaction in which certain parts of the body, such as the throat, airways, skin, or bloodstream, suddenly become very sensitive to an allergen. These allergies, called “anaphylactic” reactions, are usually triggered by certain foods, or insect bites or stings, and can be prevented by taking an allergy shot, which gives the body a small amount of the allergen, so that the body becomes used to it and can no longer have an allergic reaction. For example, if you have a bee sting, you could get stung again and again, as long as you take an allergy shot beforehand, and your body will be accustomed to the bee sting.
